author: greysonmage
content:
I was reading acd summaries from <@552133098075193354> and <@812183289224757278> (thanks as usual for those!). I had a thought/question about public testnet vulnerabilities post merge. An attacker/troll was able to mess with ropsten ttd timing at fairly low cost, because it's a testnet and normally has low hash rate. 

Could someone similarly throw a wrench into post merge testing efforts, by controlling a lot of stakeweight? If validator activation is often rate limited, they would need to plan ahead to build up stakeweight over time. But with very young beacon chains, there will be less eth staked, and this sort of attack will be much easier to do -- they just need to make sure they are a substantial fraction of all eth going through the queue during its relatively short life.

Have you guys thought about this / how to mitigate it? Or maybe I just misunderstand something and this isn't actually something that can happen?

author: jgm
content: Long-term testnets will have a lot of validators from the start.  As such, it won't be possible for someone to quickly take a large percentage of the validators.

author: killari.
content: https://barnabe.substack.com/p/pos-ethereum-reorg?sd=fs&s=r "The issue would not have happened were all validators running the same configuration! In particular, it would not have happened post-Merge, as all validators must hard-fork to the Merge updates previous to the Merge, or be entirely kicked out of the consensus.", is the boost consensus rule after the merge but not currently?

author: benjaminion
content: Pre-Merge, proposer boost was deemed optional, so users are updating ad-hoc. But all users must update for the Merge, so then it will reach 100% deployment.

author: killari.
content: can you still maliciously run a node that doesnt do that?

author: benjaminion
content: Of course. Anyone can do what they like - it's a permissionless system.

author: killari.
content: right, but I guess how the network would react to that. I guess there are no profitable attacks with that as youself would just get reorged

author: benjaminion
content: Yes, unless you can get to >50% with a wonky fork choice (as per last week's event), then it will be unprofitable to deviate from the majority view of the chain. You are always rewarded for agreeing with the majority and penalised for disagreeing.
